title-group.article-title: Xenon gas as a potential treatment for opioid use disorder, alcohol use disorder, and related disorders

article-meta.aff: McLean Hospital, Harvard Medical School, Belmont, MA, USA

author-notes.corresp: *Correspondence to: Marc J. Kaufman, PhD, kaufman@mclean.harvard.edu.

abstract.p: Xenon gas is considered to be a safe anesthetic and imaging agent. Research on its other potentially beneficial effects suggests that xenon may have broad efficacy for treating health disorders. A number of reviews on xenon applications have been published, but none have focused on substance use disorders. Accordingly, we review xenon effects and targets relevant to the treatment of substance use disorders, with a focus on opioid use disorder and alcohol use disorder. We report that xenon inhaled at subsedative concentrations inhibits conditioned memory reconsolidation and opioid withdrawal symptoms. We review work by others reporting on the antidepressant, anxiolytic, and analgesic properties of xenon, which could diminish negative affective states and pain. We discuss research supporting the possibility that xenon could prevent analgesic- or stress-induced opioid tolerance and, by so doing could reduce the risk of developing opioid use disorder. The rapid kinetics, favorable safety and side effect profiles, and multitargeting capability of xenon suggest that it could be used as an ambulatory on-demand treatment to rapidly attenuate maladaptive memory, physical and affective withdrawal symptoms, and pain drivers of substance use disorders when they occur. Xenon may also have human immunodeficiency virus and oncology applications because its effects relevant to substance use disorders could be exploited to target human immunodeficiency virus reservoirs, human immunodeficiency virus protein-induced abnormalities, and cancers. Although xenon is expensive, low concentrations exert beneficial effects, and gas separation, recovery, and recycling advancements will lower xenon costs, increasing the economic feasibility of its therapeutic use. More research is needed to better understand the remarkable repertoire of effects of xenon and its potential therapeutic applications.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Xenon is a rare noble gas best known in the medical field as an inhaled anesthetic and imaging agent, applications in which it is considered to have good safety and side effect profiles, even in critical care patients.123456 Reviews on the effects of xenon, including its use as an anesthetic378 and imaging agent,1459 organoprotective,1011 neuroprotective,711121314151617 and analgesic18 effects, potentially beneficial effects in people with posttraumatic stress disorder,19 and pleiotropic biological and molecular effects,20212223 have been published. The utility of xenon for treating substance use disorders (SUDs) was hypothesized in 2006 on the basis of a study reporting that xenon blocked both amphetamine-induced dopamine release and locomotor sensitization.24 However, in the interim, only a handful of additional studies evaluating the effects of xenon directly relevant to SUDs have been published,25262728 all of which support the possibility that xenon could be an effective SUD treatment. To our knowledge, no comprehensive review on xenon’s potential for treating SUDs exists.

Accordingly, this review outlines xenon’s effects and known targets relevant to SUDs, in particular, opioid use disorder (OUD) and alcohol use disorder (AUD). Together, these SUDs account for large mortality, public health, and economic burdens in the United States.29 The multitarget effects of xenon could be especially beneficial in people living with comorbid SUDs and psychiatric disorders, which are prevalent and difficult to treat.303132333435

We discovered two potentially beneficial effects of subsedative xenon administration relevant to SUDs: the inhibition of conditioned memory reconsolidation (MR)36 and the inhibition of physical opioid withdrawal (abstinence) symptoms.27 Others have reported that xenon reduces anxiety, depression, and pain symptoms, which emerge in people living with SUDs when their preferred substances are unavailable, a dysfunctional state termed hyperkatifeia.29 Maladaptive memories, physical withdrawal symptoms, and hyperkatifeia perpetuate SUDs by preventing people from initiating or maintaining SUD treatment,29373839 which leads to inferior outcomes. Our working hypothesis is that xenon could help attenuate these effects and improve SUD treatment outcomes. We used several databases to identify relevant literature, including PubMed (National Library of Medicine), Web of Science (Clarivate), and Google Search. We also searched bibliographies of relevant manuscripts to identify additional pertinent literature. All publication years were eligible for inclusion. We used manuscript keywords as key search terms.

sec.title: The Physical Properties of Xenon Make It a Multitargeting Agent
sec.p: Xenon has numerous beneficial effects because it acts as a multitarget agent. The molecular targets of xenon have been identified in the biological and physiological studies described in several reviews.112123 The xenon “interactome” was further expanded by analytical studies using X-ray crystallography, nuclear magnetic resonance, in silico screening, and protein oxidation or proteolysis detection to reveal dozens of additional possible targets.2022404142 Potential SUD-relevant targets, e.g., α1-adrenergic receptors, have been identified via the use of pressurized xenon to force it into protein fissures and gaps.42

Xenon interacts with many targets because it is relatively small in volume, has high lipid solubility, and is highly polarizable, enabling it to behave like a solvent that occupies and disrupts the external and internal protein cavity and lipid domains, thereby constraining molecular fluctuations and functions.41434445 The xenon targets we consider most likely to have therapeutic potential for treating or preventing SUDs include ionotropic neurotransmitter receptors, kinases, potassium and calcium channels, monoamine transporters, and lipid rafts, which often act in tandem in bidirectional mutually reinforcing ways. By disrupting these interactions, xenon may be especially well suited for treating SUDs. In the following sections, we review xenon’s effects on SUDs, including its ability to inhibit conditioned MR, physical withdrawal (abstinence) symptoms, and hyperkatifeia symptoms.

sec.title: Memory reconsolidation
sec.p: SUDs have long been considered learning and memory disorders in which these normally adaptive cognitive processes are “hijacked,” causing individuals to compulsively seek rewarding or relieving effects of psychoactive substances, despite adverse consequences.46 MR is critically involved in these processes because memory directs future attention and behavior. MR occurs after a memory is reactivated by exposure to an environment (e.g., location) or cue (e.g., sight, sound, smell, or internal/interoceptive stimulus) previously associated with the memory. Environments or cues associated with pleasant (feeling good, high, or relaxed) or unpleasant (opposite effects, including aversive drug withdrawal symptoms or with the emergence of affective or tactile pain) feelings reactivate salient yet maladaptive memories that trigger substance use. Upon reactivation of a memory, its molecular structure becomes labile and susceptible to updating by strengthening (if the current experience induces an expected effect) or weakening (if no or a different effect occurs). Reconsolidation is adaptive because it enables memories to be updated so that behavior is either sustained, intensified, or changed the next time a particular environment or cue predicting reward or aversion is encountered.37474849 Reward and aversion memories are important because they direct our attention toward salient stimuli, and when these stimuli are encountered in future, they are more likely to trigger substance use or relapse.3750

We discovered that inhaled subsedative xenon inhibited fear MR in rats that had been conditioned to form an aversive memory.36 The rats were conditioned in an experimental chamber (environment) with a brief aversive (but not harmful) electric foot shock paired with an audible tone (cue). One day later, the rats were returned to the conditioning environment for 2 minutes, and the tone was played for 1 minute, but no shock was delivered. Exposure to the environment and tone reactivated memory and caused the rats to remain motionless (freeze), the standard rodent response to a fearful stimulus. Freeze time after memory reactivation (~80% of the total time; Figure 1) reflects the extent of fear associated with the memory, with shorter times indicating less fear. Immediately after memory reactivation, separate groups of rats were placed into a closed-circuit gas exposure chamber that maintained the target xenon, oxygen, and nitrogen concentrations where for 1 hour, the rats inhaled either subsedative xenon (25%/21% oxygen/54% nitrogen) or, in the same exposure chamber (to replicate exposure chamber sensations), 21% oxygen/79% nitrogen. A separate control group was exposed to normal room air. The rats were then returned to their home cages and retested with the same memory reactivation procedures to assess fear responses 2, 4, and 18 days later. Full descriptions of these experiments are found in our report.36

caption.p: Xenon (Xe) inhibits conditioned aversive memory reconsolidation.

(A) Xe (25%) inhalation (gray bars) for 1 hour given immediately after conditioned aversive memory reactivation durably and substantially inhibited conditioning environment-induced fear (% freezing time) in rats. (B) One hour of Xe treatment without memory reactivation or (C) 1 hour of Xe treatment given 2 hours after memory reactivation did not reduce freezing time. The data are expressed as the means ± SEMs (n = 7–11). *P < 0.05, **P < 0.005, vs. air controls. These data are adapted from our previous report.36

sec.p: Xenon substantially and durably reduced conditioning environment-induced freezing times for up to 18 days (Figure 1A) and induced similar effects in response to the tone cue.36 The results of these experiments revealed that xenon, in the absence of memory reactivation (Figure 1B), or xenon administered more than 2 hours after memory reactivation (Figure 1C), did not affect freezing time. In mouse experiments conducted by others using a similar aversive memory conditioning protocol, an anesthetic xenon dose (70%) given without reactivating the conditioned memory did not modify MR,51 further illustrating that xenon inhibits memory only when given after a conditioned memory is reactivated. The period during which reactivated memory is labile and can be updated is known as the reconsolidation window.5253 It remains to be determined whether the effects of xenon in animals translate to humans, although this seems likely for several reasons. First, MR mechanisms are evolutionarily conserved.54 Second, MR can be disrupted in humans,37 as discussed further below. Third, our case report study of a woman meeting the clinical criteria for posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) revealed that, after undergoing multiple therapeutic trauma memory reactivation sessions (e.g., exposure therapy) immediately followed by subsedative (15–25%) xenon inhalation, PTSD symptoms declined by nearly 80%.19 Aversive memories are also common in people living with OUD or AUD, including memories of physical withdrawal and hyperkatifeia symptoms, which lead to substance seeking and taking for symptom relief, thereby perpetuating SUDs. Accordingly, xenon, by inhibiting MR, may be able to treat maladaptive aversive memory disorders, including PTSD and SUDs.

Because aversive and appetitive (reward) MR are inhibited by glutamatergic N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor antagonists,48 xenon inhibition of NMDA receptors24555657585960616263646566676869707172 likely enables the attenuation of both MR types. Human studies are consistent with this idea by showing that the NMDA receptor antagonist ketamine or nitrous oxide administered once, after reactivation of alcohol reward memory, inhibit appetitive MR and reduce future drinking.7374 Methadone, a first-line opioid receptor agonist treatment for OUD,75 when used to reactivate heroin reward memories prior to an MR updating procedure, attenuated heroin reward MR and more effectively sustained heroin abstinence than methadone treatment as usual without MR manipulation.76 Other techniques also weaken maladaptive MR, including disgust-based counterconditioning, which reduces alcohol reward MR and problematic drinking,77 or extinction training, which persistently suppresses heroin craving.78 Notably, in these studies, higher blood ketamine concentrations after memory reactivation during the reconsolidation window predicted less future drinking in people at high risk for AUD,73 and in the methadone study, memory updating outside of the reconsolidation window was ineffective at enhancing heroin abstinence.76 These findings support our theory that xenon administration soon after reactivating maladaptive memory, within the reconsolidation window, could disrupt aversive or appetitive MR in humans with OUD, AUD, or other SUDs.

By inhibiting NMDA receptors, xenon is also expected to attenuate extinction learning,798081 a process involving new competing learning after a memory is reactivated, but the expected stimulus (e.g., alcohol or drug reward or aversive symptom relief) does not occur. Because extinction learning opposes MR, thereby weakening the effects of an existing maladaptive memory, selectively inhibiting MR while sparing extinction learning may be desirable. Xenon’s fast systemic kinetics8283848586 combined with the fact that it exerts effects almost immediately upon reaching its targets,5859616263646567697087888990 could support its administration briefly, right after maladaptive memory reactivation, to inhibit targets that mediate MR while sparing xenon-sensitive extinction learning targets. Additionally, xenon’s capacity to increase phosphatidylinositol-dependent kinase 1 (PDK-1)91 could weaken the effects of conditioned maladaptive MR by increasing protein kinase Mzeta (PKMζ) activity, which facilitates memory updating.9293 Thus, xenon could be administered in ways that leverage the MR/extinction/updating balance to favor memory extinction/updating over maladaptive MR. On the basis of findings from prior studies, we propose that the following xenon targets individually or convergently mediate its inhibitory effects on MR, although not all effects may occur in all cell types or brain areas.

sec.title: Ionotropic receptors
sec.p: Xenon inhibits NMDA receptors, including those in the amygdala, prefrontal cortex, and hippocampus, key brain areas involved in memory-related processes, by blocking the NMDA receptor coagonist (strychnine-insensitive “glycineB”) binding site.2455565759606162636465666768697071729495 This binding site is activated in vivo primarily by D-serine, which, like glycine, supports MR.9697 Xenon also inhibits α-amino-3-hydroxy-5-methyl-4-isoxazolepropionic (AMPA) receptors, including calcium-permeable AMPA GluA1-containing (also known as GluR1) receptors5961626364677198 and kainate receptors.585967 Since NMDA and AMPA receptor antagonists attenuate MR,52737499 a form of synaptic plasticity regulated by a dynamic interplay between NMDA and AMPA receptor trafficking and function,99100101102103104 xenon inhibition of both receptor types likely contributes to its ability to strongly inhibit MR.36 Xenon reportedly reduced cue-induced alcohol seeking in a rat alcohol relapse model, but because xenon was administered outside of the reconsolidation window in that study,26 it seems unlikely that MR inhibition mediated this effect. We found no reports implicating kainate receptor involvement in MR.

Xenon activates inhibitory (strychnine-sensitive) glycine receptors56105 to induce membrane hyperpolarization, an effect that could oppose excitatory NMDA or AMPA receptor-mediated membrane depolarization to inhibit MR.106 Xenon also activates inhibitory γ-aminobutyric acid receptor (GABAA) receptors,5689 which can disrupt MR.107 Xenon blocks nicotinic cholinergic α4β2, α4β456 and α788 receptors, the latter of which are linked to MR attenuation.108109110111 Serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine, 5-HT)3 receptors that support methamphetamine-related MR112 are also inhibited by xenon.5687 Figure 2 summarizes xenon’s multitarget ionotropic receptor-mediated effects that could inhibit MR, perhaps convergently, resulting in stronger MR inhibition than more selective treatments that target individual proteins.

caption.p: Xenon (Xe)-targeted ionotropic receptor effects that could mediate the inhibition of memory reconsolidation (MR).

(A) Xe inhibits and activates multiple receptors (thick arrows) shown by others (thin arrows) to enhance and inhibit MR. The known targets of xenon have yet to be confirmed as mediators of MR inhibition. Not all effects may occur in all cell types. *N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) glutamate receptor, strychnine-insensitive D-serine/glycine coagonist binding site. **Strychnine-sensitive glycine receptor binding site. Green and red lines denote activating and inhibiting effects, respectively. Absent lines reflect either no effect or current knowledge gaps. (B) Citations reporting Xe effects on receptor targets and citations reporting that these targets regulate MR. 5-HT3: 5-Hydroxytryptamine 3 subtype receptor; AMPA: α-amino-3-hydroxy-5-methyl-4-isoxazolepropionic receptor; GABAA: γ-aminobutyric acid subtype A receptor; Nic: nicotinic cholinergic receptor subtypes.

sec.title: Protein kinases
sec.p: Xenon regulates a number of kinases, including protein kinases A,113 B (also known as Akt),114115116117118119120 C,120121122 and G,123 calcium calmodulin kinase,124 p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase,121 phosphatidylinositol 3-kinases,91114119 PDK-1,91 extracellular signal-regulated kinases,117119122 mammalian target of rapamycin,120125126 and glycogen synthase kinase 3 (GSK3)114127 (Figure 3). As noted above, xenon activation of PDK-191 may increase PKMζ activity to facilitate memory updating.93 Although several kinases play important and interactive roles in memory, including in the reconsolidation of drug-related memories,128129130131132 for the remainder of this review, we focus on GSK3 for several reasons: GSK3 is inhibited, perhaps convergently, by most kinases xenon activates (Figure 3), and GSK3 expression and activity are increased by opioids133134135136 and possibly by alcohol.137 GSK3 overexpression increases alcohol consumption,138 and a synthetic GSK3β inhibitor disrupts heroin MR and reduces heroin relapse.139 GSK3 regulates physical withdrawal symptoms, hyperkatifeia, opioid tolerance, and other effects, as discussed below. GSK3, like xenon, is multitargeting, and its inhibition could amplify xenon’s multitargeting capability.

caption.p: Xenon (Xe)-targeted kinases that may mediate the inhibition of memory reconsolidation (MR).

(A) Xe activates (green) multiple protein kinases (thick arrows) known to inhibit (red lines) GSK3. Xe-targeted kinases have yet to be confirmed as mediators (thin arrows) of its ability to inhibit MR. The dotted/dashed line denotes the possibility that Xe sterically inhibits the GSK3 ATP binding site.156 Not all kinases or kinase interactions are shown. Not all effects may occur in all cell types. **GSK3α may also be targeted by these effects. (B) Citations reporting Xe kinase targets and citations reporting that these targets regulate GSK3. ATP: Adenosine triphosphate; CaMKII: calcium calmodulin kinase II; ERK1/2: extracellular signal-related kinases; mTOR: mammalian target of rapamycin; p38 MAPK: p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase; PI3K: phosphatidylinositol 3-kinases; PDK-1: phosphatidylinositol-dependent kinase 1; PK: protein kinase; PKB: protein kinase B, also known as Akt; PKMζ: protein kinase M-zeta.

sec.p: The amplification of xenon’s effects by GSK3 is plausible because GSK3 is a constitutively active multitargeting serine/threonine kinase involved in numerous key biological processes, including glycogen synthesis/glucose availability, mitochondrial function, and glutamate receptor expression and localization.140141 GSK3 exists as α and β paralogs that are widely distributed throughout the brain142143 and that share some but not all regulatory mechanisms and functions.140144145146147148 Most SUD-relevant research to date has focused on GSK3β, but GSK3α may also contribute to SUD-relevant effects; thus, in most of the following mentions, we use the term GSK3 if a paralog-selective effect is not specified. Xenon inhibits GSK3 via multiple mechanisms (Figure 3), the most well documented of which involves increasing protein kinase B (Akt) excitatory phosphorylation and activity. In turn, activated Akt inhibits GSK3114127 by increasing GSK3β serine 9 (or GSK3α serine 21) phosphorylation,140 and xenon also increases p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase activity,121 an effect that could independently inhibit GSK3β (but not GSK3α) by increasing GSK3β serine 389 (mouse) or threonine 390 (human) phosphorylation.149150151 Transgenic mice lacking the GSK3β serine 389 phosphorylation site exhibit GSK3β hyperactivity and exaggerated and prolonged fear conditioning responses.151 These mice constitute a translationally relevant model of GSK3β hyperactivity, exhibiting phenotypes comparable to those reported in people with a prevalent GSK3β single nucleotide polymorphism (rs6438552) associated with Parkinson’s disease, anxiety, and major depression.152153154 Parkinson’s disease has been associated with stimulant use,155 and anxiety and major depression are common in people living with SUDs (see below). Xenon may also directly inhibit GSK3 activity by obstructing its adenosine triphosphate (ATP)-binding site,156 a target of synthetic ATP-competitive GSK3 inhibitors developed to treat other disorders.145146157 A proteomics study supported this possibility by indicating that the xenon interactome is enriched in ATP-regulated targets.20 Interestingly, concurrent GSK3 serine 9 and GSK3β serine 389 inhibitory phosphorylation exerts additive protective effects in the heart,158 suggesting that the capacity of xenon to regulate both GSK3 inhibitory phosphorylation sites could amplify its effects.

GSK3 inhibition is likely relevant to xenon’s MR-inhibitory effects because GSK3 plays multiple key MR roles. During MR, GSK3β is activated by serine 9 dephosphorylation,159 which in turn inhibits glycogen synthase, thereby increasing the concentrations of glucose needed to optimally support synaptic plasticity.160 GSK3 inhibition also stimulates mitochondria161 to support other energy demands. Activated GSK3β regulates neuroplasticity by transiently increasing the synaptic expression of high-calcium conducting glutamate GluR1 (also known as GluA1) receptors,102103162 and GSK3β stabilizes NMDA receptor synaptic expression,163 effects that regulate the balance between long-term potentiation and long-term depression.164 Critically, serine 9 (or GSK3α serine 21) dephosphorylation enables GSK3 to enter lipid rafts165—membrane domains enriched in specialized lipids, receptors, and scaffolding proteins, including NMDA and AMPA receptors,166 that mediate signaling events and neuroplasticity. Xenon thus physically separates GSK3 from the lipid raft interactome that supports neuroplasticity, including MR. Xenon itself destabilizes artificial lipid raft preparations, an effect thought to contribute to its anesthetic effects at high concentrations,434445 raising the possibility that nonspecific lipid raft disordering also contributes to xenon’s ability to inhibit MR. Notably, xenon’s lipid raft effects are also relevant to the neurodegenerative memory disorder in Alzheimer’s disease because GSK3, amyloid-β, and Tau proteins are lipid raft interactome elements that enable Alzheimer’s disease progression.167168 These findings support the possibility that xenon could be developed to treat Alzheimer’s disease.169170 GSK3 also regulates other potentially relevant targets, including neurotransmitter transporters and brain-derived neurotropic factor expression, as discussed below.

sec.title: Neurotransmitter transporters
sec.p: Activated GSK3 increases dopamine transporter (DAT) membrane expression and DA uptake capacity.171 Because dopamine receptor activation is required for memory destabilization49 and updating,172 xenon inhibition of GSK3 could reduce DAT expression, increase synaptic DA concentrations, and enhance memory destabilization and updating. However, xenon reportedly does not increase nucleus accumbens microdialysate DA concentration,25 so changes in DAT expression resulting in increases in extracellular DA may not be required for xenon to inhibit MR. Xenon activation of PDK-191 and its downstream memory-updating kinase PKMζ9293 could support MR inhibition by enhancing memory updating, instead of or along with xenon-induced changes in synaptic DA signaling.

Xenon increases brain173174 and systemic norepinephrine (NE) concentrations,175 effects that may result from downregulated NE transporter membrane expression and activity secondary to Akt activation and GSK3 inhibition.176 While NE activates β-adrenergic receptors that support opioid177178179 or alcohol MR,180181 if xenon, under conditions that can be administered to humans, also inhibits β1-adrenergic receptors,42 NE-mediated β1AR enhancement of maladaptive MR may be limited,182 including MR of aversive opioid withdrawal-like symptoms.183184

By inhibiting GSK3 activity, xenon may also increase serotonin transporter membrane expression and activity185186 and, in turn, decrease extracellular and synaptic 5-HT concentrations. Since no studies have reported on xenon-induced 5-HT changes, it remains to be determined whether xenon alters synaptic or extracellular 5-HT concentrations. If xenon-induced serotonin transporter upregulation reduces synaptic 5-HT concentrations, this could augment xenon’s inhibition of 5-HT3 receptors5687 that contribute to MR112 and could inhibit MR mediated by other serotonin receptor subtypes.49

sec.title: Other targets
sec.p: Xenon inhibits P-type membrane calcium ATPases (PMCAs), resulting in increased intracellular calcium concentrations.187188189190 Although no studies to date have implicated PMCAs in MR, by increasing intracellular calcium concentrations, xenon could reduce the effect sizes of glutamate receptor-mediated calcium transients, the antagonism of which inhibits MR.58596162636467 Additionally, lipid raft PMCAs activate glycine transporter 2 (GlyT2) transporters,191 which are potential targets for treating pain and possibly SUDs, depressive disorders, anxiety, or seizure disorders.192 Thus, xenon’s PMCA-inhibitory effects could inhibit glycine uptake, increase synaptic glycine concentrations, and activate inhibitory glycine receptors to attenuate MR.106 This effect could confer other potential benefits mediated by glycine inhibitory transmission, as discussed below.

Xenon inhibits and increases, respectively, expression of the apoptosis protein Bax193194195 and the prosurvival protein Bcl-2.193194195196197 The resulting increase in the Bcl-2/Bax ratio could exert MR-inhibitory effects similar to those of prazosin, which blunts aversive MR.198 Xenon increases cyclic AMP response element binding protein (CREB) phosphorylation196199 and brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) concentrations,117120196 possibly by inhibiting GSK3β200201202 A xenon-induced BDNF increase could be important because BDNF increases PKMζ expression and memory updating.203 In contrast, CREB transcription factor activity is required for MR,204205 so xenon’s CREB-enhancing effect could support MR. That being said, xenon may also increase the expression of a CREB feedback inhibitor, inducible cyclic AMP early repressor protein, which limits CREB’s duration of action.206 This lithium-sensitive effect207 could be mediated by GSK3 inhibition140 and thus also by xenon. Furthermore, by increasing PKA and PKC activities and BDNF concentrations, xenon could increase inducible cyclic AMP early repressor protein expression,206 thereby countering CREB-induced MR-enhancing effects. Xenon desensitization of acid-sensing ion channels208 could decrease the lability of reactivated conditioned memory by altering AMPA receptor dynamics,209 possibly countering xenon’s MR-inhibitory effects.

We did not find reports linking the following xenon targets to MR, although several may mediate other SUD-relevant effects discussed below. Xenon activates TREK-1 potassium channels66210 and ATP-dependent potassium (Kir 6.2) channels211212213 and increases hypoxia inducible factor-1α115 and microRNA-21 (miR-21) expression.118214215 Xenon inhibits hyperpolarization-activated cyclic nucleotide-gated channels,90216 transient receptor potential vanilloid (TRPV1) receptors,217 Caspase 3,194195197218 and tissue plasminogen activator and plasmin,219 although the latter effect has been challenged.220221

To summarize, most xenon targets have the capacity to inhibit MR or enhance memory updating, which is consistent with our findings.1936 Targeting MR as an approach to treat maladaptive memory disorders has been critiqued because some studies have reported minimal or modest effects.37 Importantly, the degree of memory reactivation required for effective MR attenuation is determined in part by a particular memory’s strength and age.484979 Thus, the use of artificial or weak memory reactivating stimuli presented in artificial (research laboratory or clinic) environments may insufficiently reactivate some memories, thereby limiting the capacity to inhibit MR. Our theory is that administering (or self-administering) xenon briefly in the real world, immediately after highly salient maladaptive memories are reactivated—perhaps multiple times each day when such memories are triggered by real-world stimuli222—will be more effective at inhibiting MR than what can be achieved by laboratory or clinic MR-attenuation conditions.49 The next section reviews xenon’s ability to inhibit physical withdrawal (abstinence) symptoms, which are potent negative reinforcers that trigger substance use for symptom relief.

sec.title: Physical withdrawal (abstinence) syndrome
sec.p: Physical dependence develops after prolonged heavy opioid or alcohol use, during which highly aversive withdrawal (abstinence) symptoms emerge when blood opioid or alcohol concentrations decline. Opioid withdrawal symptoms (OWS) and alcohol withdrawal symptoms (AWS), which include diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, and cramps,38223224 are potent negative reinforcers; they or interoceptive cues predicting their onset trigger withdrawal fears and substance use to avert or relieve symptoms. Withdrawal fears prevent many people with SUDs from initiating treatment, and for those in treatment, they prompt unprescribed substance use,225 which in turn leads to relapse.29383975224226227 Accordingly, withdrawal symptom management is considered critical for optimizing OUD or AUD outcomes.293839227 OWS and AWS are caused in part by opioid- or alcohol-induced gut leakiness (dysbiosis), which enables inflammatory mediators to enter and spread through the systemic circulation, effectively causing a low level of sepsis.228229230231 The resulting systemic inflammation enhances sympathetic nervous system (SNS) activity232 and increases withdrawal symptom severity.293839223227231

We tested whether xenon could blunt opioid receptor antagonist (naltrexone)-precipitated OWS in morphine-dependent mice. After naltrexone administration, the mice were placed into a closed-circuit gas exposure chamber containing either 21% oxygen/balance nitrogen (controls) or 21% oxygen/30% xenon/balance nitrogen. After 10 minutes, the mice were moved to a normal air chamber and videorecorded for 45 minutes for behavioral scoring by a rater blinded to the treatment conditions. Our primary measure of OWS severity was the number of naltrexone-precipitated jumps. Detailed descriptions of these experiments can be found in our previous report.27 Xenon substantially reduced jumping, and its effect was rapid, apparent within the first 10-minute observation period (Figure 4). These effects are consistent with those in a human study reporting that exposure to higher (sedative) xenon concentrations reduced OWS or AWS and reduced the subsequent need for therapeutic opioid or benzodiazepine use.28

caption.p: Xenon (Xe) inhibits naltrexone-precipitated jumping counts in morphine-dependent mice.

These data are adapted from our previous report.27 No sex differences were detected, so the mice were grouped together. Xe inhalation for 10 minutes starting immediately after naltrexone injection substantially reduced jumping at all time points (*P < 0.002, two-way (treatment, time) analysis of variance). Tukey multiple comparisons post hoc analysis revealed rapid onset of the Xe effect, which was significant in the first 10-minute window (†P < 0.02). Periods 1–3 are consecutive 10-minute intervals, and period 4 is a 15-minute interval. No jumps were detected in Xe-treated mice during period 4. The data are expressed as the means ± SEMs (n = 15–26). GraphPad Prism version 10.3 was used to produce the figures and analyze the data.

sec.p: The effects of xenon on OWS may be attributable to its ability to attenuate inflammation118125233234235236237238 and SNS activity.239240241242 Intriguingly, recent work indicates that it is possible to rapidly phase in naltrexone treatment for OUD, which is significant because naltrexone, by blocking opioid receptors, is one of the most effective but most aversive and least tolerated treatments for OUD.243 By attenuating OWS, xenon could be used in combination with naltrexone to increase its tolerability and perhaps accelerate its introduction. Given that OWS and AWS are driven by comparable mechanisms, including gut dysbiosis, inflammation, and SNS hyperactivity,231 and that xenon reduces AWS in humans,28 we predict that xenon could also be used to attenuate AWS. The following xenon targets may mediate its effects on physical withdrawal symptoms.

sec.title: Ionotropic receptors
sec.p: Xenon inhibition of NMDA, AMPA, and 5HT3 receptors and activation of GABAA receptors support the possibility that these targets contribute to xenon attenuation of OWS and possibly AWS. In this regard, NMDA and AMPA receptor antagonists reduce OWS and/or AWS symptoms.244245246247248249250251252 Serotonin 5-HT3 receptor inhibition reduces OWS in animals253254255 and is moderately effective at inhibiting OWS in human neonates256 but not in adults with OUD.257 GABAA receptor activation attenuates AWS.258

sec.title: Kinases
sec.p: GSK3 may mediate xenon’s effects on OWS and AWS because GSK3 positively regulates SNS activity259260261262 and inflammation.263264 Furthermore, opioids increase GSK3 expression and activity,133134135136 as may alcohol,137 potentially enhancing OWS or AWS severity by increasing SNS activity and inflammation. GSK3 inhibitors of several different chemical classes, including lithium, insulin, and synthetics, attenuate OWS,265266267 and the GSK3 inhibitor lithium reduces AWS severity.268

sec.title: Transporters
sec.p: Xenon-induced increases in brain extracellular and systemic NE concentrations,173174175 possibly resulting from NE transporter downregulation,176 could activate α2 adrenergic receptors and, like the α2 adrenergic receptor agonists clonidine and lofexidine used to treat AWS and OWS,231 attenuate OWS or AWS.

sec.title: Other targets
sec.p: Chronic opioid exposure downregulates ATP-dependent potassium channels,269270271272 whereas TRPV1 activity is increased during opioid withdrawal,273 and TRPV1 receptor inhibition reduces OWS in mice.274 Accordingly, xenon activation of ATP-dependent (Kir 6.2) potassium channels211212213 and/or inhibition of TRPV1 receptors217 could attenuate OWS or AWS. The probiotic activity of xenon could favorably impact the gut microbiome275 and counter opioid- or alcohol-induced gut dysbiosis, leakage, and the systemic inflammation that drive SNS hyperactivity and AWS or OWS.231

In summary, most xenon effects predict its ability to attenuate OWS or AWS (Figure 5). If xenon is administered as withdrawal symptoms emerge, it may dually blunt withdrawal symptoms and aversive MR of those symptoms, perhaps exerting additive effects that reduce present and future motivation to seek withdrawal symptom relief via substance use.

caption.p: Xenon (Xe) targets that could mediate its inhibition of withdrawal symptoms or seizures.

Xe inhibits (thick red arrows) physical opioid withdrawal symptoms (OWS)2728 and seizures276277278279280281282 and may inhibit alcohol withdrawal symptoms (AWS). (A) Xe inhibits (thick red arrows) and activates (thick green arrows) several targets/effects that have yet to be confirmed as mediators (thin arrows) of its ability to inhibit withdrawal symptoms or seizures. Not all effects or interactions are shown. Not all effects may occur in all cell types. Absent lines indicate either no effect or current knowledge gaps. (B) Citations reporting Xe targets and citations reporting that these targets regulate withdrawal symptoms or seizures. *Effects in animals and human neonates but not adults. 5-HT3: 5-Hydroxytryptamine 3 subtype receptor; AMPA: α-amino-3-hydroxy-5-methyl-4-isoxazolepropionic receptor; KATP (6.2): ATP-dependent potassium (6.2) channels; AWS: alcohol withdrawal symptoms; GABAA: γ-aminobutyric acid subtype A receptor; GSK3: glycogen synthase kinase-3; NE: norepinephrine; OWS: opioid withdrawal symptoms; TRPV1: transient receptor potential vanilloid-1 receptor.

sec.title: Alcohol withdrawal seizures
sec.p: One of the most serious withdrawal symptoms that can occur after prolonged heavy alcohol use is the development of seizures.223 Xenon’s anticonvulsant effects276277278279280281282 could be employed to reduce seizures. Xenon inhibition of excitatory NMDA and AMPA glutamate receptors and activation of inhibitory GABAA or glycine receptors or KATP (6.2) channels predict its antiseizure activity.223277278280282283284285286287288289 The next section discusses the negative emotional state of hyperkatifeia, a substance withdrawal phenomenon that also catalyzes relief seeking via substance abuse.

sec.title: Hyperkatifeia: Negative Emotional States That Emerge During Drug Unavailability
sec.p: People who use opioids, alcohol, and other substances, including anabolic steroids, cannabis, cocaine, MDMA, methamphetamine, and nicotine experience affective symptoms, including anxiety, depression and dysphoria, as well as pain symptoms, when their substance is unavailable.290 This leads to the emergence of a negative emotional state called hyperkatifeia.29 Although milder than physical withdrawal symptoms, hyperkatifeia similarly prompts relief seeking through continued or renewed substance abuse. Hyperkatifeia tends to occur early in the course of SUDs, as neural systems adapt to the presence of alcohol or drugs, a process called tolerance (discussed below), during which escalation of opioid, alcohol, or other substance use is required either to experience rewarding effects or to relieve aversive effects.29 Reward or relief become more difficult to achieve as tolerance increases, and ultimately, aversive symptom relief becomes a primary goal of substance use.29

Xenon reduces hyperkatifeia symptoms, including anxiety,1936236241242275291 depression/dysphoria,120236275292293 and pain and its sensitization.18718284233272294295296297298299300 Accordingly, xenon administered as hyperkatifeia symptoms emerge could provide relief that otherwise would be attained through substance use. Xenon targets that could mediate its antihyperkatifeia effects are described below.

sec.title: Ionotropic receptors and ion channels
sec.p: Xenon modulation of ionotropic receptors and ion channels predict its ability to attenuate hyperkatifeia symptoms. In this regard, NMDA receptor antagonists reduce anxiety,96301 depression,302303304 and pain.18305306307 AMPA receptor antagonists exert anxiolytic effects,308 enhance depression symptoms,308309310 and inhibit pain and pain sensitization.18306 Kainate receptor antagonists reduce depression symptoms311312 and pain311 but increase anxiety.312313 Glycine receptor activation reduces anxiety and depression symptoms, including those associated with alcohol withdrawal,314 and reduces pain.315 TPRV1 antagonists attenuate depression, anxiety, pain, and hyperalgesia, including in alcohol-withdrawn rats.18273306316317 Hyperpolarization-activated cyclic nucleotide-gated channel inhibition reduces pain,18318 and ASIC antagonists attenuate depression-like behaviors,319 anxiety,320 and pain.306320 PMCA inhibitors, by inhibiting glycine transporter (GlyT2) uptake,191 can increase synaptic glycine concentrations and activate glycine receptors, effects associated with the attenuation of depression, anxiety, and pain.321 ATP-dependent (Kir 6.2) potassium channel agonists decrease pain,270271272 and TREK-1 potassium channel activators may increase depression while decreasing pain.322

sec.title: GSK3
sec.p: Xenon inhibition of GSK3 predicts antidepressant,153323324 anxiolytic,325 and analgesic effects,326327 including antihyperalgesia effects.328329

sec.title: Transporters
sec.p: Xenon-induced increases in NE concentrations173174175 secondary to NE transporter downregulation176 could exert antidepressant, anxiolytic, and analgesic effects.330331332 By inhibiting GSK3, xenon could also upregulate serotonin transporter expression and activity,185186 thereby decreasing synaptic or extracellular 5-HT concentrations. Such an effect has yet to be demonstrated, but if it occurs, it could oppose the antidepressant effects of xenon. However, a recent systematic review challenged the serotonin theory of depression.333

sec.title: Other targets
sec.p: The effects of xenon on several other targets predict its antidepressant, anxiolytic, and analgesic effects. In this context, increases in BDNF and phosphorylated CREB exert antidepressant334335336 and antianxiety337338 effects, increases in hypoxia inducible factor-1α are associated with antidepressant339 and analgesic340 effects, and increases in miR-21 promote antidepressant341 and analgesic342 effects. Caspase3 reductions are associated with analgesia,343 whereas gut dysbiosis and inflammation are associated with depression and anxiety,228231344345346 effects potentially countered by the probiotic effects of xenon.275

In summary, most of xenon’s known molecular effects are consistent with its ability to reduce or relieve hyperkatifeia symptoms (Figure 6). Accordingly, xenon could fill what is considered a hyperkatifeia treatment gap.29 More human data on how xenon moderates hyperkatifeia symptoms may result from registered clinical trials (Clinicaltrials.gov) aimed at evaluating xenon as a treatment for major depressive disorder (NCT03748446), posttraumatic stress disorder (NCT03635827), panic disorder (NCT04432155), and “psychoemotional” stress (NCT06080100).

caption.p: Xenon (Xe) targets that may moderate hyperkatifeia symptoms of major depression, anxiety, and/or pain.

(A) Xe inhibits (thick red arrows) depression,120236275292293 anxiety,1936236241242275291 and pain.18718284233272294295296297298299300 Xe activates (thick green arrows) and inhibits (thick red arrows) targets that have been shown by others to inhibit or enhance hyperkatifeia symptoms. Xe targets have yet to be confirmed as mediators (thin arrows) of its antidepressant, anxiolytic, or analgesic effects. Absent lines indicate either no effect or current knowledge gaps. (B) Citations reporting Xe targets and citations reporting effects of these targets on hyperkatifeia symptoms. **Strychnine-sensitive glycine receptor binding site. AMPA: α-Amino-3-hydroxy-5-methyl-4-isoxazolepropionic receptor; ASIC: acid-sensing ion channel; BDNF: brain-derived neurotrophic factor; HCN2: hyperpolarization-activated cyclic nucleotide-gated channel; KATP (6.2): ATP-dependent potassium (6.2) channel; GSK3: glycogen synthase kinase-3; miR-21: microRNA-21; NE: norepinephrine; pCREB: phosphorylated cyclic-AMP-response element binding protein; PMCA: P-type membrane calcium ATPases; TREK-1: two-pore-domain background potassium channel; TRPV1: transient receptor potential vanilloid-1 receptor.

sec.title: Tolerance
sec.p: During exposures to opioids, alcohol, or other drugs, physiological adaptations occur that result in tolerance, which requires escalating substance doses to achieve rewarding or relieving effects.29 Opioid analgesic tolerance develops quickly, within hours, faster than tolerance for opioid-induced respiratory depression, meaning that if opioid dose escalation is used to preserve analgesia (or rewarding or relieving effects), the risk increases for overdose due to respiratory depression.347 Tolerance often leads to substance misuse and the development of dependence, especially OUD and AUD.29 For example, an estimated 3.7 million pain patients in the US misused prescribed opioid analgesics in 2021.348 Accordingly, developing treatments that limit tolerance could help prevent the development of OUD and perhaps other SUDs.

To date, no research has directly tested whether xenon blunts opioid tolerance. However, the analgesic effects of xenon at subsedative concentrations, which are not mediated by opioid receptors and are not subject to rapid tolerance, along with its opioid-sparing ability and ability to prevent hyperalgesia,18718284233272294295296297298299300349 support our theory that xenon has strong potential for use as an opioid-sparing treatment. Xenon, if used in combination with opioid analgesics, could limit opioid dosing requirements for effective pain relief, thereby reducing the risk of OUD development.350

Because NMDA,351352353354355356 AMPA,351357 5HT3253254358 receptor inhibitors, GSK3 inhibitors,266359360361362 KATP channel openers,270272 TRPV1 channel antagonists,363364 and gut microbiome enhancers365 prevent or reduce opioid tolerance, and because TREK-1 channels activated by xenon66210 mediate opioid analgesia but not opioid tolerance,366 xenon’s multitargeting effects predict its ability to attenuate opioid tolerance (Figure 7).

caption.p: Xenon (Xe) targets that could attenuate opioid tolerance/hyperalgesia.

(A) Xe inhibits (thick red arrows) and activates (thick green arrows) targets that reportedly increase and decrease, respectively, opioid tolerance/hyperalgesia (thin arrows). (B) Citations reporting Xe targets and citations reporting the effects of these targets on opioid tolerance/hyperalgesia. 5-HT3: 5-Hydroxytryptamine 3 subtype receptor; AMPA: α-amino-3-hydroxy-5-methyl-4-isoxazolepropionic receptor; KATP (6.2): ATP-dependent potassium (6.2) channels; GSK3: glycogen synthase kinase-3; TREK-1: two-pore-domain background potassium channel; TRPV1: transient receptor potential vanilloid-1 receptor.

sec.p: Additionally, because our bodies release endogenous opioids to limit the effects of stress and to accelerate stress recovery,367368369 endogenous opioid tolerance also develops in people exposed to prolonged stress. Stress-induced opioid tolerance increases susceptibility to future stresses and pain and leads to greater preference for exogenous opioids,367368370371372373374 perhaps as a form of self-medication that counters low endogenous opioid efficacy.375376377 For example, having PTSD increases the risk of developing OUD following opioid analgesic use.378 Conversely, prior chronic morphine exposure potentiates aversive memory formation and enhances fear learning,379 an effect mimicked by opioid antagonists that blunt endogenous opioid effects.380381382 Moreover, high proportions of opioid users either experience or witness drug overdoses,383 which are stressful events that increase the risk of developing PTSD.384 Together, these seemingly bidirectional processes likely contribute to the high comorbidity of stress disorders such as PTSD with OUD,385386387388 either or both of which could benefit from xenon’s multitargeting effects.

sec.title: Drug reward and preference
sec.p: Many psychoactive substances, including alcohol, opioids, and stimulants increase dopamine concentrations, a neurochemical signal of reward and an effect that results from interactions between multiple neurotransmitter signaling systems.389 Alcohol or drug preference develops after rewarding (or relieving) effects trigger neuroplasticity, including the formation of memories that support alcohol or drug seeking.390 Accordingly, interventions that can inhibit reward signals could help disrupt the chain of behaviors and allostatic changes that increase the risk of developing SUDs.29

Xenon attenuates stimulant (amphetamine and ketamine)-induced dopamine increases2425 and alcohol seeking26, indicating that it could be used to limit alcohol or drug reward, as well as memories of their rewarding or relieving effects. The xenon inhibition of nicotinic α7 and α4β2 receptors5688 predict its ability to attenuate dopamine increases that signal nicotine reward.391 Xenon reward-attenuating effects are predicted for these and other substances through their multitargeting of ionotropic receptors,247390391392393394 ion channels,395396 GSK3,137138373397398399400401402403404405406 and the gut microbiome.407408409

sec.title: Human immunodeficiency virus and GSK3
sec.p: Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) is relevant to this review because it is highly comorbid with SUDs410411 and because SUD/HIV comorbidity is associated with increased risks for psychiatric and medical impairments of greater severity that lead to worse outcomes.411412413414415416417 By inhibiting GSK3, xenon targets an important intersection between HIV and OUD or AUD: GSK3 is regulated not only by opioids and alcohol but also by the HIV proteins transactivator of transcription (Tat) and glycoprotein 120 (gp120).134418419420421422423424425426 Tat protein likely contributes to ongoing HIV pathophysiology despite antiretroviral therapy because during effective antiretroviral therapy, Tat protein continues to be synthesized and released from HIV reservoirs to impair brain function and physiology.427428429 Selective Tat protein expression in animal models induces memory impairments,430431432433434435436 anxiety- and depression-like phenotypes,434437438439440441 pain-like phenotypes,441442443444 and analgesic tolerance,445446 effects analogous to those found in people living with HIV. Tat protein also induces dopamine system deficits and alters stimulant-related behaviors,447448449450 perhaps by upregulating DAT expression, a downstream effect of GSK3 activation.171 Tat protein also enhances ethanol reward.451 GSK3 has been proposed as an HIV therapeutic target,452 and GSK3 inhibitors including lithium, valproic acid, and synthetics, attenuate the effects of Tat or gp120 protein-mediated HIV effects.6134418420421425453 These findings support the possibility that xenon inhibition of GSK3 could exert several different beneficial effects on HIV. The inhibition of GSK3 by xenon could also be exploited to reactivate antiretroviral therapy-resistant viral reservoirs,454455456457 increasing their vulnerability to attack, elimination, and HIV cure.458

sec.title: Xenon Slows the Development, Invasiveness, or Progression of Cancers
sec.p: While cancers might seem out of the scope of this review, accumulating evidence suggests that xenon multitargeting effects relevant to SUDs, including the inhibition of ionotropic glutamate and nicotinic receptors and GSK3, may have therapeutic potential for treating cancers, including the brain cancer glioblastoma multiforme (GBM).140157459460461462463 GBM is the most common type of brain tumor; it is aggressive, its prognosis is poor (median survival time of ~15 months), and treatment options are limited and compromised by tumor resistance.464465

Xenon inhibition of glutamate receptors could be beneficial in GBM because these glial cell-like tumors (gliomas) secrete glutamate to activate local NMDA and AMPA receptors, which increase tumor growth,466467 induce excitotoxicity in surrounding host tissues,468 and enhance DNA repair,469 conferring tumor resistance by limiting chemo- or radiotherapy efficacy. GBM glutamate release also induces seizures.468 Direct evidence supporting the efficacy of xenon against GBM comes from a cell culture study reporting that 50% xenon sensitizes GBM cell lines to radiation therapy.470 By inhibiting GSK3, the concentrations of which are elevated in GBM cells,471 xenon can exert this and several other beneficial effects. For example, the synthetic GSK3 inhibitor kenpaullone sensitizes GBM stem cells to chemotherapy (temozolomide) treatment,472 and the GSK3 inhibitor tideglusib reduces GBM cell line proliferation and viability and increases radiation sensitivity.473 The GSK3β inhibitor TDZD-8 slowed tumor growth and prolonged survival in a mouse GBM model.474 GSK3 inhibition could also enhance several immune system effects that are beneficial for targeting GBM, including by augmenting the effects of immune checkpoint inhibitors or chimeric antigen receptor therapy, by enhancing natural killer cell sensitivity and activity, and by increasing interferon-γ.475 Xenon increases interferon-γ signaling in Alzheimer’s disease models.170 Xenon induction of metaphase arrest in glial cells476 could also trigger glioma cell cycle arrest/senescence.477478 Xenon’s anticonvulsant effects276277278279280281282 could attenuate GBM-associated seizures,468 and in the ~20% of patients who continue to smoke despite being diagnosed with GBM,460 xenon could blunt α7 nicotinic receptor activation-induced chemo- or radiation resistance.461

Additionally, stress catalyzes the development of GBM and worsens outcomes in brain cancer patients,479480 who, in turn, have very high rates of anxiety disorders and stress,480 resulting in a vicious cycle. Accordingly, by blunting anxiety and major depression symptoms,1936236241242275291292293 xenon could slow the development, invasiveness, or progression of these and perhaps other cancers.

sec.title: Xenon abuse liability
sec.p: Xenon reportedly induces mildly pleasant subjective experiences up to and including euphoria at high subsedative concentrations.481482 However, in rats, subsedative (43%) xenon does not increase the concentration of extracellular dopamine in the nucleus accumbens,25 a biomarker of reward.389 Furthermore, xenon decreases amphetamine- or ketamine-induced dopamine increases,2425 suggesting that it is likely to inhibit stimulant and perhaps other substance-induced reward signals. By blocking the NMDA receptor glycine/D-serine binding site,60 xenon is predicted to reduce the reinforcing effects of morphine247 or alcohol392 and to reduce motivation either to self-administer or reinstate ketamine seeking.394 NMDA receptor glycine/D-serine binding site inhibitors also fail either to generalize to phencyclidine effects483 or to induce psychotomimetic effects,484 predicting that xenon does not have appreciable abuse liability. Additional support for this idea comes from neurophysiological studies reporting that xenon does not induce open channel NMDA receptor blockade,70 differentiating it from other NMDA receptor antagonists with abuse liability, including ketamine, MK-801, or phencyclidine. If additional testing confirms this theory, it is plausible that xenon could be used as an ambulatory patient-controlled treatment for SUDs. Additionally, by mimicking some of the effects of alcohol, including by inhibiting NMDA receptors via interactions with several of the same receptor domains as alcohol and by activating GABA and glycine receptors,5672 xenon could be developed as a nonaddictive agonist substitution treatment for AUD.258 Xenon could be superior to existing treatments that mimic some of the properties of alcohol, including NMDA receptor antagonists, benzodiazepines, and barbiturates, each of which has significant abuse liability.223258485 Given xenon’s broad therapeutic potential for treating SUDs, additional abuse liability studies, including human studies, clearly are warranted.

sec.title: Xenon costs now and in the future
sec.p: Xenon is obtained primarily during air purification via cryogenic distillation, an energetically costly process of finite capacity.486487 This contributes to the high cost of xenon, which is a barrier to its therapeutic use. However, new xenon purification methods utilizing sophisticated molecular separation methods are being developed488489490491 to lower purification costs and enable high-efficiency xenon recovery and recycling from exhalates.492 Furthermore, the high xenon concentrations needed for anesthesia (60–70%) and evaluated in many studies of xenon effects are not necessary to exert potentially beneficial effects. In our studies, subsedative xenon concentrations (15–30%) inhibited aversive MR1936 and naltrexone-precipitated morphine withdrawal symptoms.27 Multiple treatments with xenon (15–30%) reduce anxiety in panic disorder patients.291 Subsedative (35%) xenon inhibited α7-nicotinic receptor-mediated signaling,88 18–30% xenon inhibited NMDA and AMPA glutamatergic signaling,61626367 25% xenon conferred neuroprotection after transient brain ischemia,493 and 30% xenon attenuated human infantile asphyxial seizures.276 Much lower xenon concentrations (0.5–1%) administered briefly to humans intraocularly inhibited the perception of and brain activation patterns associated with pain and its sensitization.82 Microliter-volume xenon concentrations administered to neuronal cell cultures via lipid emulsions inhibited NMDA receptor currents.69 Similarly, the administration of microliter xenon concentrations in vivo to rodents via liposomes increased the brain concentrations of BDNF and phosphorylated Akt (which inhibits GSK3) while exerting antidepressant effects.120236 In rodent brain injury studies, microliter volume xenon concentrations given once or repetitively conferred neuroprotection, preserved motor function, increased the expression of beneficial mediators including BDNF and phosphorylated Akt, or improved the gut microbiome.117195275494495 An important focus for future research should be to expand our knowledge of the effects of xenon at low concentrations to determine threshold effective concentrations for different indications.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This review illustrates that xenon has strong potential for therapeutic development to treat and possibly prevent opioid, alcohol, stimulant, and other SUDs, HIV, and certain cancers. By concurrently targeting multiple proteins that regulate SUD-related processes in beneficial ways, xenon could be more effective than more selective agents, e.g., glutamatergic NMDA receptor antagonists,496497 at inhibiting multiple stages in the chain of events that lead to or sustain SUDs, including alcohol or drug reward/preference, memory, tolerance, or physical, affective, or pain-related withdrawal symptoms, and the maladaptive memories they induce or strengthen (Figure 8).

caption.p: Xenon has the potential to prevent or disrupt SUDs by concurrently interfering with multiple steps in the progression of feed forward effects that enable or sustain SUDs. The green and red arrows represent activating and inhibiting paths, respectively. SUDs: Substance use disorders; MR: memory reconsolidation.

sec.p: While much is known about xenon’s targets and effects, many critical knowledge gaps exist. Xenon dose-effect and pharmacodynamics studies are needed to help identify optimal administration protocols to achieve beneficial effects. For example, could xenon be inhaled briefly after maladaptive memory reactivation to disrupt MR while sparing effects of xenon-sensitive extinction learning mechanisms? Abuse liability and safety testing are needed to determine whether xenon could be made available to patients for real-world on-demand use when maladaptive memories, physical withdrawal, or hyperkatifeia symptoms emerge. This is the time at which xenon, by attenuating maladaptive memories and symptoms that trigger risky drinking or substance use for reward or relief, could be especially beneficial, including by disrupting MR. This mode of treatment could help people resist future alcohol or drug urges or cravings. The potential of xenon to attenuate opioid tolerance merits study because mitigating opioid tolerance could reduce the risk that prescription opioid analgesic use will lead to OUD.

Given the numerous roles that GSK3 plays in moderating SUDs and other disorders and the fact that inhibition of its constitutive activity could amplify xenon’s multitargeting effects, it will be important to better understand how xenon affects GSK3α and β paralogs and differentially impacts cytosolic and nuclear processes in different cell types.149150151 Furthermore, it will be important to characterize targets of potential therapeutic relevance, such as α1 adrenergic receptors42, to determine whether xenon inhibits receptor activity under dosing conditions suitable for human use. Our hope is that this review will stimulate interest in conducting research to answer these questions, new ones that will emerge, and that future xenon research will lead to novel treatments that benefit people living with SUDs, HIV, cancers, and other disorders.

They received past research support and royalties from Nobilis Therapeutics, Inc. MJK is a consultant for Pop Test Oncology LLC and Ria Technology Management, Inc.

sec.p: No additional data are available.
